ground_truth_answer: While both are dangerous, slug bait containing metaldehyde is significantly more dangerous than Easter grass for dogs. A 10-pound dog can show severe poisoning from just 1 ounce of slug bait containing 3% metaldehyde, with approximately 25% of affected dogs dying. Symptoms include vomiting, seizures, and can lead to death without immediate treatment. Easter grass, while also hazardous if ingested, typically causes less severe issues like vomiting, straining to defecate, and abdominal pain, though it still requires immediate veterinary attention.
